msDesc.head: 'Murbach Hymnal'; glossaries Junius A, Junius B, Junius C; etc. A-J: Germany (Murbach, Reichenau, etc.), 8th and 9th centuries

summary.p: This manuscript is famous for its early German glosses and glossaries, and also preserves important copies of other encyclopaedic, grammatical and theological texts. It is comprised of nine or ten separate 'libelli', which are attributed on palaeographical grounds either to Murbach abbey, to its mother-house Reichenau, or to the area of south-west Germany and Lake Constance. Inscriptions on fols. 1v, 103v and 194r show that the volume was in something like its present form at Murbach in 1461 when it was in a poor state of repair and restored by the abbot.

msItem.note:
Table of contents as follows: 1. Cosmagraphia Ethici philosophi
2. Albinum ad carolum de Rhetorica Et Philosophia
3. Epistola Ieronimi de Musicalibus instrumentis
4. Vocabularium secundum ordinem alphabeti
5. Expositio super fidem Athanasii Et pater noster
6. Item super aliquos ymnos
7. Ysidorus in principio Ethimologiarum
8. Item interpretacio hebraicarum questionum

physDesc.p: Composite: nine or ten codicogical units and endleaves (fols. 1, 194). The enumeration differs according to whether fols. 116–129 (the Murbach Hymnal section) are considered as one codicological unit or as two; they are considered here as separate units.

history.provenance: Murbach, Benedictine abbey: inscription 'Legentes in hoc libro orent pro Reuerendo domino bartholomeo de andolo cuius industria pene dilapssus renouatus est anno M CCCC lxj' (fol. 103v); Orent legentes pro domino bartolomeo de andolo Morbacen. abbate (fol. 194r).
Marcus Zuerius Boxhorn, Leiden (d. 1653): ownership inscription 'Sum Boxhorni' (fol. 2r)
Isaac Vossius (d. 1689): glossaries A, B, C and the Murbach hymns cited in Junius's Glossarium Gothicum as in Vossius's library.

recordHist.source:
Description by Tuija Ainonen and Matthew Holford (April 2020, rev. Oct. 2020). Previously described in the Summary Catalogue.
Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 969 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 970 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 971

availability.p: To ensure its preservation, access to this item is restricted, and readers are asked to work from reproductions and published descriptions as far as possible. If you wish to apply to see the original, please click the request button above. When your request is received, you will be asked to contact the relevant curator outlining the subject of your research, the importance of this item to that research, and the resources you have already consulted.

msItem.title: Antiphonal
msItem.note: Parts of two bifolia bound sideways. Many smaller fragments used for repairs elsewhere in the volume.

supportDesc.extent: Parts of two bifolia (fols. 1, 194) cropped and bound in sideways 273 190 Width of one leaf, 200 mm.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col. Width of the written space 120–5 mm.

msItem.author: Ps.-Aethicus
msItem.title: Cosmographia
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber ethici translato philosophico edito oraculo Hieronimo presbytero dilatum ex chosmografia id est mundi scriptura edicta ethici philosophi chosmografi
msItem.incipit: Philosophorum sciedolas sagacei indagatione
msItem.explicit: quos nos indaganter inuestigauimus. Suos characteres litterarum quos adinuenit ita distinxit
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber ethici philosophi cosmografi, natione schitica, nobile prosapia parentum, ab eo enim ethica philosophia a reliquis sapientibus originem traxit.
msItem.note: Followed by 22 'letters' and their names in three columns.

Siglum O in the edition of O. Prinz, MGH QQ zur Geistesgesch. 14 (1993). Fols. 4v, 5v blank; text continuous; one leaf missing after fol. 50 with loss of text (Prinz 213.3–218.7). Marginal notes added in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries by more than one hand.

origin.origPlace: German, southwest, perhaps Murbach, Benedictine abbey, according to Bischoff, II, no. 3799

msItem.note: Various short notes and glosses in Latin, some containing Greek, on an originally blank folio.

msItem.author: Alcuin
msItem.title: Rhetoric
msItem.rubric: Qui rogo ciuiles cupiat cognoscere mores haec percepta legat quaelibet iste.
msItem.incipit: Quia te venerande magister Deus adduxit et reduxit
msItem.explicit: legentem non corrumpit
msItem.note: The treatise ends in a series of diagrams, fols. 72v-75v.
ed. PL 101, col. 919ff.
Notes on penance added after the end of the text (fol. 72r), before the diagrams on fol. 72v:
msItem.incipit: ANCYRITANA .xlviiij. Si quis adulterium commiserit .vii. annis penitencie completis perfectione redditur secundum pristinos gradus

msItem.incipit: Cogor a te ut tibi Dardane de aliis generibus musicorum

handDesc.handNote: At least two different hands writing in Caroline minuscule.

history.origin: 9th century, first quarter German, southwest , according to Bischoff, II, no. 3800

msItem.author: Alcuin

msItem.title: Carmen 82
msItem.incipit: O rex auguste clarissime dignus honore et dux et doctor

msItem.title: Carmen 85.II
msItem.incipit: Te homo laudet Alme creator

msItem.note: Added in the 9th century on a previously empty folio.
ed. Ernst Dümmler, Poetae Latini aevi Carolini, MGH, Poetae latini, vol. 1, pp. 300, 303.

msItem.title: Glossary ('Junius B', 'Jb')
msItem.incipit:
Abram pater excelsus hohfater
Abram pater multorum
msItem.explicit: Uncia uam unicus cuius que rei xii. pars sicut est uncia in libra
msItem.note: The glossary is constructed from glosses to the Biblical books Genesis – I Kings, with additional glosses (usually marked with ał) included from the Homilies of Gregory the Great. Each letter of the alphabet starts a new column. A glossary to the Dialogues of Gregory the Great is added in the free spaces in a different hand on fols. 89ra, 91ra, 92rb, 93ra-b, 94ra and 102rb. See E. Krotz in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), 216–7

layoutDesc.layout: Written in two columns, c. 24–25 lines, unruled.

history.origin:
8th century, end-9th century, beginning
Germanic centre in the region of Lake Constance , according to Bischoff, II, no. 3801
history.provenance: Murbach Abbey: glosses added early 9th century perhaps by the scribe of the Murbach Hymnals and the Junius C glossary (Krotz, op. cit.).

msPart.head: Commentaries on the Creed and the Pater Noster

msItem.author: Venantius Fortunatus
msItem.title: Commentary on the Athanasian Creed
msItem.incipit: Quicumque vult salvus esse ... Fides dicitur credulitas sive credentia

msItem.author: Pelagius
msItem.title: Libellus fidei ad Innocentium papam
msItem.incipit: Credimus in Deum patrem omnipotentem, cunctorum visibilium et invisibilium conditorem ...
msItem.explicit: non me ereticum conprobabit. Dolendum est non querere homines eterna quae certa sunt sed sperare.

msItem.title: Commentary on the Lord's Prayer
msItem.incipit: Pater noster qui es in caelis; haec vox libertatis est
msItem.explicit: Sed libera nos a malo; a diabolo vel a malis hominibus.
msItem.note: PL 138.1184, as part of the Expositio missae 'Primum in ordine'; cf. Stegmüller, Bibl. 9045, 9352 (attrib. Alcuin).

msItem.author: Jerome
msItem.title: Commentary on the Lord's Prayer
msItem.incipit: Pater noster qui in caelis es. Patrem dicendo se filios confitentur
msItem.explicit: Recte ergo et hii quibus peccata dimittuntur homines appellati sunt.
msItem.note: PL 26.42–3; Stegmüller, Bibl. 3372,4
msItem.textLang: Latin, with a couple of Greek words

history.origin:
9th century, beginning German, Murbach, Benedictine abbey
, according to Bischoff, II, no. 3802

msContents.summary: The second part of the 'Murbach hymns'. Bischoff suggested that the first part of the hymns (part G = fols. 122–129) was written at Reichenau with the first recto left blank, and circulated as an independent quire which soon reached Murbach. There the present quire (fols. 116–21) was added and the original collection supplemented by five or six additional hymns on the first two leaves. The remaining leaves of both quires (fols. 118–21 of the present quire, and the originally blank spaces of part 7) were used for glossaries and grammatical texts.

msItem.note: Hymnal, with Old German interlinear translation: ‘The Murbach Hymns’, XXII-XXVI

msItem.title: Hymnal
msItem.note: Chevalier 600, 20328, 17393, 647, 20075, 20086. For classification as a Frankish hymnal see H. Gneuss in Mittellateiniches Jahrbuch35 (2000), 228.

msItem.title: Murbach Hymnal XXII-XXVI
msItem.incipit: euuige christes lon intj urchundono kauuirich

msItem.note: The hymn 'Te decet laus' (fol. 117r) was treated by Sievers as no. 25a, but is regarded by others as an independent item (L. Voetz, in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), p. 273).
Written with the Old High German translations directly above the Latin texts, in a Murbach hand of the early 9th century.
Eduard Sievers, Die Murbacher Hymnen (Halle 1874); C. Simboloti, Gli Inni di Murbach: edizione critica, commento e glossario (2009).

msItem.title: Glossary ('Junius C', 'Jc')
msItem.incipit:
ortfrumo
thara uuidri
em mizi

Auctor
At contra
Assiduitate
msItem.explicit: uuint linder in uuintar

Zephiri lenes uent
que uerno tempore
msItem.note: In the same hand as the scribe of the hymns also present in this manuscript; in four columns, arranged alphabetically, but leaping from D to M as the central bifolium of the quire has fallen out. There are one or two additions in the same hand as those on 89r–102v. See E. Krotz in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), 217–19.
msItem.bibl: E. Krotz, Auf den Spuren des althochdeutschen Isidor: Studien zur Pariser Handschrift, den Mondseer Fragmenten und zum Glossar Jc (Munich 2000), pp. 159–259.

layoutDesc.layout: Hymns written in 25 long lines, with interlinear German glosses.

history.provenance: For date and origin see L. Voetz, in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), p. 274, summarizing earlier literature.

msItem.title: Glossary to the Benedictine Rule
msItem.incipit:
kizogenen lungorun
kispreitta

Alumnis
Propagium
msItem.explicit: Priuata
kiskerita
msItem.note: In the same hand as the previous glossary. The text begins on 122r (that is, on the first leaf of part 7), before breaking off midway through the fifth column. It then continues in the left hand margin of 121v, then in the free space in the fourth column of 121v, and finally returns to the free space in the fifth column of 122r. In the initial columns on 122r, the German equivalents are entered above the Latin. After the break midway in the fifth column, however, the Latin is entered not in full Carolingian minuscule, but in the same hand used for entering the German text, and so the German text occurs sometimes above, sometimes alongside and sometimes below the Latin terms thereafter. (Mossman, c. 2003)
A subsequent hand has entered a tiny portion of a different glossary to the Benedictine Rule in the bottom right-hand corner of fol. 122r. (Mossmann, c. 2003).
See A. Masser in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), 46–9.
Hymnal, with Old German interlinear translation: ‘The Murbach Hymns’, part I (nos. I-XXI).
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt hymni canendae per circulum anni hymnum ad noctem dominicis diebus

msItem.title: Hymnal I-XXI
msItem.incipit: Mediae noctis tempore prophetica uox admonet
msItem.explicit: ab omni mortis inpetu tuum defendas populum

msItem.title: Murbach Hymns I-XXI
msItem.incipit: mit tera nahti zite uuizacl lichiu stimma manot
msItem.explicit: fona allemu todes analaufte dinan kascirmi liut

msItem.note: These are in a different hand from those hymns of part 6, although organised in the same manner upon the page, with the Old High German text above the Latin. (Mossman, c. 2003).
Eduard Sievers, Die Murbacher Hymnen (Halle 1874); C. Simboloti, Gli Inni di Murbach: edizione critica, commento e glossario (2009).
Added grammatical text.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 20 long lines, with interlinear German glosses.

handDesc.handNote: Caroline minuscule. Fol. 122v attributed by Bischoff (II, no. 3803) to Reginbert of Reichenau.

decoDesc.decoNote: Good initials. (Pächt and Alexander i. 5, pl. I)

history.provenance: For date and origin see L. Voetz, in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), p. 274, summarizing earlier literature.

Probably not identifiable with the volume described 'De carminibus Theodiscae volumen I' in the Reichenau booklist of 821–2, or with volumes ('...XII carmina Theodiscae linguae formata', '...carmine diversa ad docendum Theodiscam linguam') in the Reichenau booklist of 835 × 842 (Voetz, op. cit., 283–4).

msItem.incipit: Uidentur uerba ex forma gerendi perfecto in passiuum uersa
msItem.explicit: utinam latus essem
msItem.note: Cf. Diomedes, Ars grammatica (Keil, Grammatici Latini I, 357.4–361.36).
Fols. 130r, 133v blank.

history.origin: 9th century, first quarter Reichenau, Benedictine abbey , according to Bischoff, II, no. 3805.

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: Etymologies
msItem.incipit: Domino meo et Dei seruo
msItem.note: Followed by a list of chapter titles for book 1.
msItem.incipit: Disciplina a discendo nomen accepit
msItem.explicit: et quintiliano sed ita copiose ita uarie ut eadem lectori
msItem.note: Incomplete, books 1–2,2; text ends abruptly on fol. 151v with two lines of text; the rest of the folio is blank.

Includes isolated Old High German glosses, both marginal and interlinear, on fols. 137r, 147v and 148v. The glosses are edited in Steinmeyer, Elias, and Eduard Sievers (eds.), Die althochdeutschen Glossen, 5 vols (Berlin 1879–1922), no. 493.

decoDesc.decoNote: Capitals in the ink of the text.

history.origin:
9th century
German, Murbach, Benedictine abbey (?) , according to BStK 795 (III)

msItem.note: (extracts)
msItem.incipit: Donatus dicit partes orationis sunt octo
msItem.explicit: De interiectione ... nec in aliam linguum facile transferentur.
msItem.bibl: Grammatical works attributed to Peter of Pisa, Charlemagne's tutor, ed. E. Krotz and M. Gorman (Weidmann: Hildesheim, 2014), sig. J, pp. xlv, xlvii.

msItem.incipit: Sunt nomina tota mobilia ut doctus .ta .tum. Et ideo mobilia dicuntur
scolasticus . scolasticum
msItem.note: Cf. E. Krotz, Auf den Spuren des althochdeutschen Isidor (2002), 237–9; H. Hagen, Anecdota Helvetica (1870), xxix.

msItem.incipit: Inter participia presentis temporis et nomina eorum similia
Species uocum alii .ii. alii .iiij. dixerunt esse
msItem.explicit: intellegitur per gemitis dolor
msItem.note: Krotz and Gormann, 301–2; cf. H. Hagen, Anecdota Helvetica (1870), xxv-vi (Bern MS. 207 f. 115v-116r)

msItem.title: De littera
msItem.incipit: Genera litterarum diuersa sunt quia a diuersis locis et auctoribus
msItem.explicit: non diuiditur athomos est. Finit.
msItem.note: H. Hagen, Anecdota Helvetica (1870), xxv-vi (Bern MS. 207 f. 112r-113r)

msItem.incipit: Quid est arbor .
msItem.explicit: Lucius uero ait: cumque hic tam formosus homo apta dignius puellus

msItem.note: Carm. 32 De salvatore
msItem.incipit: Christe potens rerum redeuntis conditor aevi
msItem.explicit: Annua sinceri celebrent ieiunia sacri

msItem.note: Carm. 13 In podagricum

history.origin: 8th century, end or 9th century, beginning German, southwest , according to Bischoff, II, no. 3807

msPart.head: 'Junius A' glossary; Isidore; expositions of the Pater Noster; etc.

msItem.title: Glossary ('Junius A', 'Ja')
msItem.incipit: Bresith hebreum nomen Genesis grecum in lacmadis generatio Prologus prefatio siue proloquutio
msItem.explicit:
Penetrare ingan
Aporia suintilod
Diuinatio urteili
msItem.note: Glosses to a substantial part of the Bible, to Biblical poetry, saints' lives and grammatical texts; see E. Krotz in Althochdeutsche Literatur, ed. by Rolf Bergmann (2013), 213–216.
Excerpts from Book VII.6-Book VIII.2

msItem.rubric: De nominibus qui de quodam presagio nomina acceperunt
msItem.incipit: Plerique primorum hominorum
Quorundam patriarcharum ethimologiae notandae sunt
Quos gentiles uater apellant
Martyres greca lingua latine testes dicuntur
Cleros et clericos hinc appellatos
Monachus greca ethimologia uocatur eo quod sit singularis
Christianus quantum de interpretatio
Ecclesia grecum est quod in lation uertitur conuocatio
msItem.explicit: quasi inter Deum et hominem hinc et fedus.

msItem.note: Commentaries on the Lord's Prayer, etc.

msItem.incipit: Dominus et saluator noster discipulis suis petentibus quemadmodum orare deberent
msItem.explicit: conferre dignetur iesus christus dominus noster qui uiuit et regnat

msItem.incipit: Pater noster qui es in caelis; ut filius esse merearis ecclesiae; caelum est ibi ubi culpa
msItem.explicit: a malo hoc est de inimico et de peccato preterito ac presenti et futuro

msItem.incipit: Pater noster que es in celis Patrem inuocamus deum in caelis quia nos omnes ab uno deo omnipotente creati sumus
msItem.explicit: a diabolo et ab omni opere malo uel de inferno amen

msItem.title: ‘Expositio de fide catholica’

msItem.incipit: Aurea uos summi conseruet dextera patris

history.origin: end of the 8th century-beginning of 9th century German, Lake Constance region (?) , according to BStK 795 (IV) and Bischoff, II, no. 3808 (without the date)
